New funding available! Heathrow Community Trust's new round of our Environment and Sustainability grant programme opened today, 22 August, and closes on 24 October. This programme awards grants of up to Â£15,000 for projects with a total cost of up to Â£60,000. The following themes apply for this programme, and applicants should select the theme that best fits their project: T1 Supporting the community by supporting sustainable development T2 Protecting and enhancing our natural environment T3 Promoting Reduce, Reuse, Recycle Further information and the application form are on our Environment and Sustainability page https://lnkd.in/eXKg6337 It is important that applicants read through our Grant Making Policy and Tips for writing your funding bid document before applying for this funding. As we close out 2023, Kilmac reflects on a year marked by milestones, recognitions, and a steadfast commitment to community engagement. It's been a journey of growth, achievement, and giving back, and we're thrilled to share the highlights that define our remarkable year. Awards Galore: Kilmac soared to new heights in 2023, earning awards that affirm our dedication to excellence. We were honoured to secure a spot on the Fast Growth 50 in Scotland, a testament to our rapid expansion and contribution to the regional economy. The SME Awards crowned us as the Civil Engineering Company of the Year, recognising our innovation and impact in the industry. Adding to the excitement, Callan reached the final of the Scottish Apprenticeship Awards, showcasing our commitment to nurturing and celebrating emerging talent. Welcoming Fresh Faces: This year, Kilmac opened its doors to 61 new team members, each contributing to the vibrant tapestry of our company culture. Among them, we proudly welcomed 3 graduates and 2 apprentices, investing in the next generation of industry leaders. These additions strengthen our capabilities and reflect our commitment to fostering a diverse and skilled workforce. Community Contributions: Â£72,325.14 and Counting: At Kilmac, we believe in making a positive impact beyond construction sites. In 2023, we donated a total of Â£72,325.14 to local community projects through financial contributions and in-kind support. This commitment to community betterment is at the core of our values, and we look forward to continuing these efforts in the years to come. Education and Insight: 87 Hours Spent on Local School and College Visits: Empowering the next generation with knowledge and insight into the world of civil engineering has been a priority for Kilmac. Over the past year, our team dedicated 87 hours to school and college visits, engaging with students, and providing a first-hand understanding of the industry. These interactions aim to inspire future leaders and create pathways to success. As we celebrate these accomplishments, we acknowledge that they are a result of the collective efforts of our dedicated team. Looking ahead, Kilmac remains committed to innovation, sustainability, and community engagement. Here's to a year of growth, recognition, and making a positive impact on the world around us.

CAN chair Ken Parkin and board member Stuart Miller recently met with Geraldine Cunningham and Donna Nicole from the Economic Development Team at Newcastle City Council to discuss partner working and key regional construction themes. We were delighted to hear about the excellent work the Council is doing to facilitate new entrants into the local construction industry, while driving social value outcomes. The continuing skills shortage being felt by construction firms across the North East was also discussed, with Stuart explaining many of his CECA members are encountering difficulties in recruiting and training groundworkers and plant operators. We hope that moving forward we can work on a more joined up approach between industry and regional partners. The Councilâ€™s newly introduced Construction Talent Pool, which links to developments in Newcastle and incorporates built in training and employment management plans secured through planning agreements and conditions, looks set to transform recruitment drives for Newcastle residents and we will continue discussions on how businesses can get involved with the talent pool and employment across the city. There was extensive conversation surrounding apprenticeships and how we can work together on mutually beneficial grounds to identify trade apprenticeship options and help signpost applicants to recruitment opportunities through the Skills Hub and other outlets. Geraldine and Donna did advise that they would be happy to receive further input and intelligence on how the Council can best support the construction sector around recruitment though. Moving forwards, we are planning to reconvene in 2-3 months to pick up on our action points. #ConstructingTheRegion #SkillsShortages #Construction #Meetings #NewcastleCityCouncil #CAN #NorthEast #Apprentices #Recruitment

So, Bristol City Council planning team is being overseen by the government to support the backlog of applications..... I have visions of a big bus arriving at the council offices with hundreds of Planners pouring out of the back and racing in to pick up applications and save the day.... I suspect this isn't the case! But I am keen to understand exactly how it will work. And, if it is a workforce issue in terms of not having enough staff, what more can we do to help? Something is stuck in the pipe - I know schools, colleges and universities are doing a good job at promoting planning, the apprenticeship system can help, there are on the job training roles available and mentors who want to support growth so is it a leadership issue or a structure issue? Is it that people aren't wanting a career in planning or is the system just in need of a huge overhaul? I am no expert at all and may sound a little flippant as I don't work in those overworked planning teams - but I'd love to hear your thoughts. Is the 'housing crisis' infact a planning crisis?
